title: World Foundation Models - Computerphile
description:
Discussing World Foundation Models with TJ Galda from Nvidia.

Computerphile is supported by Jane Street. Learn more about them (and exciting career opportunities) at: https://jane-st.co/computerphile

This video was filmed and edited by Sean Riley.

Computerphile is a sister project to Brady Haran's Numberphile. More at https://www.bradyharanblog.com

comments.author: @diffpizza
comments.comment: Nice useless corpo propaganda

comments.author: @raulgalets
comments.comment: Here, have my sony camera battery so your papers do not fly off

comments.author: @Mercury1234
comments.comment: Will we ever get past this shitty brute force solution of just feeding even more data into the network? Will it ever be able to infer and deduce things from only a few samples? Or do we just keep increasing the model sizes until they become too expensive to train and infer?

comments.author: @hhhsp951
comments.comment:
A lot of people in this comments section are throwing shade on industry professionals in place of university academics and I would just like to remind you all that those university academics would not have a job if they weren't advancing things for industry to use
A lot of people in these tech spaces are legitimately making advancement, it's just that instead of getting paid to work in an academic setting on a somewhat defined set of projects, they are getting paid for directly solving a more specified set of problems for a corporatized entity
I wouldn't work for Nvidia AI, or any AI company, but why are you knocking someone who would? We all need a paycheck right now, and it's mad easy to pay no mind to the deep rooted issues around in academia.

comments.comment:
I with ML since 2017 and I was living under the impression that I understand the current developments but after watching this video I have no idea what this "world model" is. 

This explanation is way too high level -  and  circles with "data",  statements "you don't have to program it" and "post-training" do not help understanding the mechanisms of how exactly they are trained and what they do

comments.author: @TimothyWhiteheadzm
comments.comment: Re: synthetic data with a bear at night. The main problem I foresee is that the correct reaction may be different for a bear at night or in fog or in the daytime so generating synthetic data that says you should behave the same in all those scenarios is dangerous. You will end up teaching cars to drive at night in the fog the same as if it is broad daylight with full visibility.

comments.author: @aturaki
comments.comment:
Cool stuff.
I can't wait for the day,
when there are many, many world models out there,
and they start breeding together,
creating new children,
with AI kindergarten!

Maybe that is what I should focus on for my next career, AI kindergarten teacher!

comments.author: @cosmiclettuce
comments.comment:
What do foundation models do?  They generate solutions to problems.  What do they need?  **DATA** -- high-quality, real-world, continuous, and labeled.

What do humans do?  They generate data.  What do they need?  **SOLUTIONS TO PROBLEMS** -- clear, concise, and complete.

I will provide an ongoing, diverse, genuinely unique, and useful real-world labeled data stream to foundation model builders (pretrainers and fine-tuners) if they provide an ongoing stream of cash to me.

comments.author: @DeclanMBrennan
comments.comment:
Brute force training is not the way humans or far simpler animals become good at interacting with the world where specific situations are sometimes encountered for the very first time. I can see a model being useful if the algorithm is able to do "What if" reasoning with it. ¬†

We need more tools in the algorithm toolbox so we're not trying to hammer a nail in with a screwdriver and when unimpressed with the result, we keep buying more boxes of screwdrivers so we can get the nails in faster.

comments.author: @doublepinger
comments.comment: Until they have "3d game" accelerators. Any type of "real-world" model is still just a neural net which is making no "recurring" logical. It's weird AI training is invested in billions and billions of hours, kilowatt-hours, dollars, and yet there's no model which has a recursive structure??? Like, neurons do one thing, have persistent back-and-forth, not form a concrete front-to-back computation. Even a 4-function calculator can operate on its last state. Current AI is just a huge grifting experiment right?

comments.author: @chianasgeek6730
comments.comment: 03:28 made me think of Monty Python's 'Ministry of Silly Walks'. Sorry; not sorry!

comments.author: @tinyminus
comments.comment: He says that AI has a coherent world algorithm, but approximating reality doesn't necessarily mean the AI understands the rules behind it. That can be seen in the videos and photos AIs generate. If it truly understood physics, then wouldn't those hallucinations go away? I'm not anti-AI, but I'm skeptical that current LLMs can achieve true understanding. But I'm not an expert. If there are any experts in the comments, I'd like to know if I'm completely wrong. Or if I'm right, what breakthroughs are still needed?

comments.author: @Lucas357915
comments.comment: I see we're still trying to see all types of bear instead of understanding what a bear is...

comments.author: @DeoMachina
comments.comment:
I'm conflicted, because while the underlying technology and theory behind ML is very interesting, I can't pretend like current LLM implementations aren't making my life worse in every regard.
Giving some of the big AI companies a platform to put their points across, while taking sponsorship from Jane Street (itself a finance company invested in ML) just doesn't sit right with me.

So in our brain, we have to reverse-translate that first in order to understand wth is going on.

comments.author: @memorytospeedcode
comments.comment:
How can I export a simulation generated by NVIDIA COSMOS‚Äînot just as a rendered video, but as an editable world or environment‚Äîinto a simulation platform like Gazebo or Webots, so that I can place my robot inside it and begin interactive testing? In other words, does COSMOS support exporting simulated environments (with physical properties intact) in a format compatible with these platforms, or does it only provide physics-compliant videos that must be treated as non-interactive visual data for passive training purposes?

edit: Can someone also please explain ISAAC SIM (built on Omniverse) and how does it exactly work and compare with simulators like Gazebo?
Thanks
Another "Machine learning will solve everything, trust me bro" ü§°
